history.content: I would leave out 161, rather than picking between 168 and 186 since both are very industry related. Despite the interesting material in 161, it wouldn't be very useful in general if you do not go down the security path.

children.subject:
I'd take 161, 162, 168, 170. 

Security is extremely practical, as it networking. OS and DB are also fundamental courses, but slightly less practical than the previous two. I'd choose OS over DB as you'll be dealing with OS primitives a lot more often (threading, FS, etc.) than with DB primitives. Ideally you'd take both, of course.

The idea that the material in 161 isn't very useful unless you're going 100% security is utterly wrong: lack of security fundamentals is one of the reasons so much shoddy software gets exploited all the time, and 161 gives you a rather practical taste of how exploitation is done so you can learn to write better, more secure code to avoid exploitation, not to mention the useful introduction on things like keys, symmetric/asymmetric encryption, etc. Definitely take 161 if you're planning on a career as a software developer, you'll be dealing with the things you learn in 161 all the time.

history.content:
I'm a rising junior and I have 5 classes which I really want to take over the next 2 years. They are: CS 161, 168, 186, 162, 170. Since I am double majoring, realistically I can only take 4 of them. Everyone at this university and their mother is urging me to take 170. I also think 161 will be really cool, and 162 will be really useful.

I have two questions:

1. Between 168 (Networking) and 186 (Databases), which is more useful in industry or better in general? 

2. If you had to choose only 4 out of CS 161, 168, 186, 162, 170, which would you pick?
history.subject: 168 vs. 186
